page.title: 01THE BEDGEBURY AREA
page.content: Bedgebury Forest covers sandy ridges of the High Weald, farming preferring the clay valleys. Names and features recall the former iron industry. The manor of Bedgebury once covered much of this area, the house and park now a girls' independent school. The Forest and Great Lake are much used for recreation. Activities are sometimes "sponsored" for charity fund-raising or pursued by Duke of Edinburgh's Award candidates. The fauna and flora interest both amateur and professional observers. Bedgebury Pinetum is a scientific collection and a tourist attraction. The local rail line is now disused but the A229 bus route serves the hamlets of Hartley and Gill's Green. Social matters mentioned here range from local smuggling legend to international humanitarian concern.
